name: K2-223
scenarioDescription:
The K2-223 Exoplanetary System

K2-223 is a star with 1.06 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.99 times its radius. It is located 655.90 light years away from the solar system.

K2-223 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

K2-223 b

K2-223 b was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2018-02. Its semi-major axis is 0.01 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 0.51 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-223.

The mass of K2-223 b is 0.72 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-223 b is 0.89 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, K2-223 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

K2-223 c

K2-223 c was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2018-02. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 4.56 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-223.

The mass of K2-223 c is 2.84 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-223 c is 1.57 that of Earth. At 2.84 Earth masses, K2-223 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system K2-223, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by K2.
